content.raw:
> But we need docker to run further, right?

Right!?! If you follow the steps, the `nvidia-container-toolkit` should have installed docker \(i.e. what you do get when you run `Step 5`\).

> So many?

There are only two Docker tutorials for environment setup. The former was refactored to use the prefer native Nvidia packages \(otherwise follow the link in its note\) and a new docker tutorial was added to mirror the Cloudsim environment locally.

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
For me it is also unclear how the docker solution container can be built and changed during development. In the tutorials I found descriptions how to download and run the docker containers with the tunnel world. But the part for the own solution is either the running of an existing solution \(subt\_example in the SystemSetupDockerhub\) or is describing the usage of catkin \(Cloudsim\) in the solution container. 

As a newbie to docker I might be wrong, but I came to the impression that all changes in the container are lost after shutting down the container and restarting it. We solved this problem by using a workspace folder that is a folder on the host system that is linked into the docker container by the startup of the container. But I don‘t think that this is the correct usage.

So, any description how the solution container can be setup and used during development of the own solution would be very helpful.

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
Hi @{5c0d82b3128c7106f57691a7} , I can help you with the container thing. It is true that once you close your container, all the changes are lost. What you can do is to save it as docker image. It will then hold that instance of your container.

‌

e.g.

1. You have container c1 running,
2. You made changes to some folder/files in it,
3. store the container by the following command,  
  `docker commit <CONTAINER_ID> <YOUR_GIVEN_IMAGE_NAME>:<TAG_NAME>`  
  you can get the CONTAINER\_ID by running `docker ps` and choose the image name as you wish. What I found earlier that `run.bash` script searches for the image with the tag name as `latest`. So, you can run the command as below,  
  `docker commit fed9418314dc my_image:latest`  
  and your image is ready with all your changes.
4. Next time you use your custom image by using `./run.bash my_image` and you will get all your changes there. This is how I used to keep my changes intact previously.

I need to check the current methods though. You can create a number of images like that to retain your different changes.

‌

Hope it helps. Let me know if you have any other doubts.
content.html:
Hi @Sophisticated Engineering , I can help you with the container thing. It is true that once you close your container, all the changes are lost. What you can do is to save it as docker image. It will then hold that instance of your container.

‌

e.g.

  1. You have container c1 running,
  2. You made changes to some folder/files in it,
  3. store the container by the following command,
    docker commit <CONTAINER_ID> <YOUR_GIVEN_IMAGE_NAME>:<TAG_NAME>
    you can get the CONTAINER_ID by running docker ps and choose the image name as you wish. What I found earlier that run.bash script searches for the image with the tag name as latest. So, you can run the command as below,
    docker commit fed9418314dc my_image:latest
    and your image is ready with all your changes.
  4. Next time you use your custom image by using ./run.bash my_image and you will get all your changes there. This is how I used to keep my changes intact previously.

I need to check the current methods though. You can create a number of images like that to retain your different changes.

‌

Hope it helps. Let me know if you have any other doubts.

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
Let me clarify that you do NOT need run `docker commit` commands or do development inside the docker container.

We do encourage teams to use the Docker image to run the _**SubT Virtual Simulator**_; while you continue developing your solution in your local catkin workspace and later spinning out Docker image\(s\) of your solution to be tested with [Docker Composer](https://docs.docker.com/compose) before submitting it onto the Clousim \(as shown below\). HTH!

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2746003896-solution_ws.png)
content.html:
Let me clarify that you do NOT need run docker commit commands or do development inside the docker container.

We do encourage teams to use the Docker image to run the SubT Virtual Simulator; while you continue developing your solution in your local catkin workspace and later spinning out Docker image(s) of your solution to be tested with Docker Composer before submitting it onto the Clousim (as shown below). HTH!

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
Hi baila,

See answers/comments below:

```
1. I have my local catkin workspace which contains my codes, now what should be the next step till submission?
2. How to use that subt virtual simulator?
```

For #1 and #2 above, I suggest testing your code against the _SubT Simulator_ locally first using the testbed docker image \(`subt-virutal-testbed:latest`\). This should allow you to debug and test your controller\(s\).  Here is a quick example:  

```
# Open Terminal 1 and run the Virtual Testbed image with the robot configurations for your solution

$ mkdir -p ~/subt_testbed && cd ~/subt_testbed

$ wget #!/osrf/subt/raw/tunnel_circuit/docker/run.bash

$ ./run.bash osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest tunnel_circuit_practice.ign worldName:=simple_tunnel_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1


# Open Terminal 2, go to your solution catkin workspace, and launch it as described for the subt_seed example

$ cd ~/subt_solution

$ source install/setup.bash

$ roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1

# Just replace [subt_solution] with the name of your catkin workspace and [subt_seed] with the name of your solution.
# It's common for people to use the same name for both though.
```

All the above is documented in the [Wiki](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/Home).

‌

```
3. Where/How to use that Docker Composer?
```

You use Docker Composer once your solution has been embedded inside a [Docker image](https://docs.docker.com/develop/develop-images/dockerfile_best-practices/). I suggest you take a look at the [Dockerfile in subt\_seed repo](#!/osrf/subt_seed/src/default/docker/subt_solution/Dockerfile) as a reference to create the image for yours.

‌

```
4. What is the final ‘thing’ to be submitted?
```

The final `thing` to submitted is the Docker image of your solution. Not the sim, not the bridge, not the testbed; just your solution code inside a Docker image.  However, we recommend competitors to run some simple/practice worlds in Cloudsim before going for their final real run.

HTH!
content.html:
Hi baila,

See answers/comments below:

1. I have my local catkin workspace which contains my codes, now what should be the next step till submission?
2. How to use that subt virtual simulator?

For #1 and #2 above, I suggest testing your code against the SubT Simulator locally first using the testbed docker image (subt-virutal-testbed:latest). This should allow you to debug and test your controller(s). Here is a quick example: 

# Open Terminal 1 and run the Virtual Testbed image with the robot configurations for your solution

$ mkdir -p ~/subt_testbed && cd ~/subt_testbed

$ wget https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/raw/tunnel_circuit/docker/run.bash

$ ./run.bash osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest tunnel_circuit_practice.ign worldName:=simple_tunnel_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1


# Open Terminal 2, go to your solution catkin workspace, and launch it as described for the subt_seed example

$ cd ~/subt_solution

$ source install/setup.bash

$ roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1

# Just replace [subt_solution] with the name of your catkin workspace and [subt_seed] with the name of your solution.
# It's common for people to use the same name for both though.

All the above is documented in the Wiki.

‌

3. Where/How to use that Docker Composer?

You use Docker Composer once your solution has been embedded inside a Docker image. I suggest you take a look at the Dockerfile in subt_seed repo as a reference to create the image for yours.

‌

4. What is the final ‘thing’ to be submitted?

The final thing to submitted is the Docker image of your solution. Not the sim, not the bridge, not the testbed; just your solution code inside a Docker image. However, we recommend competitors to run some simple/practice worlds in Cloudsim before going for their final real run.

HTH!

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
Baila,

Running the `osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest` docker image is equivalent to running `ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign ...` from a local Subt workspace \(e.g. `subt_ws`\)

You can use [Cloudsim](https://www.subtchallenge.world/) to test your solution \(_using simple and practice worlds_\) and to submit your \(one-time only\) final solution for the Tunnel Circuit competition.

You can include the `worldName` parameter in the local launch command. Practice worlds have 20 artifacts.

Finally, I really encourage you to go through the [documentation](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/Home). it will provide you with more details and it can save you time.
content.html:
Baila,

Running the osrf/subt-virtual-testbed:latest docker image is equivalent to running ign launch tunnel_circuit_practice.ign ... from a local Subt workspace (e.g. subt_ws)

You can use Cloudsim to test your solution (using simple and practice worlds) and to submit your (one-time only) final solution for the Tunnel Circuit competition.

You can include the worldName parameter in the local launch command. Practice worlds have 20 artifacts.

Finally, I really encourage you to go through the documentation. it will provide you with more details and it can save you time.

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
For a functionality standpoint, they are equivalent.  However, the former will be downloaded from [DockerHub](https://hub.docker.com/r/osrf/subt-virtual-testbed/tags) \(at least once\) while the latter will be launched locally once you have built the [catkin workspace](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupInstall).

‌
content.html:
For a functionality standpoint, they are equivalent. However, the former will be downloaded from DockerHub (at least once) while the latter will be launched locally once you have built the catkin workspace.

‌

issue.title: SystemSetupDockerInstall should contain the docker installation step

content.raw:
Hi Baila,

That one is probably not ideal because it has commands to download the models; which you don’t need in your solution. I suggest you use the one in the [subt\_seed repo](#!/osrf/subt_seed/src/default/docker/subt_solution/Dockerfile) as starting point reference. I’d use it like this \(just an idea\):

```
$ mkdir -p ~/subt_solution/src && cd ~/subt_solution/src

$ hg clone #!/osrf/subt_seed

$ cd ~/subt_solution
```

Then, I copy all my solution code into the [/src](#!/osrf/subt_seed/src/default/src/) directory

Modify the [Dockerfile](#!/osrf/subt_seed/src/default/docker/subt_solution/Dockerfile) to install the packages required by my solution.

Build my solution docker image using the [build.bash](#!/osrf/subt_seed/src/default/docker/build.bash) script.

```
./build.bash subt_solution --no-cache
```

I hope this helps.
content.html:
Hi Baila,

That one is probably not ideal because it has commands to download the models; which you don’t need in your solution. I suggest you use the one in the subt_seed repo as starting point reference. I’d use it like this (just an idea):

$ mkdir -p ~/subt_solution/src && cd ~/subt_solution/src

$ hg clone #!/osrf/subt_seed

$ cd ~/subt_solution

Then, I copy all my solution code into the /src directory

Modify the Dockerfile to install the packages required by my solution.

Build my solution docker image using the build.bash script.

./build.bash subt_solution --no-cache

I hope this helps.
